Page 1 of 1 STRATFORD -- A controversial request for a drive-through to accommodate a possible future fast-food restaurant at the site of the former Keating Ford car dealership at 1055 Stratford Ave. was withdrawn at a public hearing Wednesday night.
On the table is a development proposal by the property owner, Gary Genga of Properties of Armando Genga Limited Partnership, to convert the site's empty buildings into what Nicholas Owen of Sultan Realty Management, who is representing Genga, described as "contemporary, village-style" retail shops. The plan also includes the construction of a free-standing structure to house a restaurant.
About 20 residents turned out to the public hearing, which replaced a July hearing deemed invalid after town officials said the Connecticut Post failed to print a legal notice submitted for publication by the town.
No one from the public spoke in favor of the proposal to develop the parcel, known to locals as Hards Corner , described by members of the public as a "strategic corner," "cornerstone," "keystone," and an "opportunity."
Zoning Commission member Robert Galello earned steady applause when he summed up the commissions' major concern: "We want the aesthetics of the Town of Stratford to go up ... and the only way to do it is to increase the value of our town -- not by putting up another drive-up fast food restaurant."
Midway through the hearing, Owen withdrew the request for a drive-through. But he noted that he may approach the commission about a drive-through in the future if the development is unable to lure a sit-down restaurant.
George C. Mulligan , whose home borders the Keating Ford property, described the proposal, now stripped of the drive-through request, as "a little bit better." But he argued that without a concrete roundup of potential tenants, the development plans remain vague.
"As it stands right now, they still could put in an X-rated video parlor," he said.
In a prepared statement, Mayor John A. Harkins voiced his opinion on the proposal, while noting the property as a "prime site for economic development."
"Conceptually, I am in favor of utilizing this property for retail development as a means of expanding our grand list and combating blight," he said.
"I have concerns with the application that is currently pending before the Zoning Commission, though I believe they can be resolved amicably. The plans as they are currently drafted are aesthetically deficient and not designed to attract the quality of retail activity I would like to see as part of redevelopment in the South End."
